div.opener:
I wish you
would
tell me as
soon as you
know who
are to be
The Commis
sioners Commissioners of Edu
cation Education who
are to come
over to
Ire-
land Ireland to re
-port report on the Irish schools.
Black Castle
June 13th, 1824.
My dear Sir
div.p:
If you have had any communication
lately with Captain Beaufort you have
heard probably of the loss we have had
if you will not have been surprised by
my silence -

Thank you for the pamphlet and
the article in the Quarterly review which
you were so good to send me. I am not
surprised that the pamphlet should have
made a great sensation in London.
It is very well written & full of good rea-
soning reasoning .- Of the points of law, of course, I
can be no judge; but taking it for grant
ed granted that the cases and precedents are
as your son states them his arguments
respecting injunctions
appear unanswerable, and the dispas
sionate dispassionate tone maintained does great
credit to the taste and judgment of
the writer - I do not feel convinced how
ever by the reasoning in the latter pages
of this pamphlet - from 34 to the end -
- I do not accede to the assertion that a Lawyer
Judge, or Chancellor is better qualified
to decide in the first instance of the im
moral immoral tendency of any book than a jury
of merchants tradesmen, yeomen & squires
- Therefore till this assertion be established
I cannot accede to the argument founded
upon it, for departing in this instance
from the spirit & usage of the British consti
tution constitution & leaving it to the Judge instead of
a jury to decide at first & at once, both of the Cause & the fact without
any hearing of the parties or of their coun-
sel counsel - That the Chancellor has been trusted
with the power of committing to prison for
contempt of their authority & that they have
not abused it & that therefore they may
be safely trusted with to judge in the case
of a book or an author where their own
passions cannot be immediately concern
ed concerned does not appear to me conclusive ar-
gument argument - It is the sort of argument whh. which
is used for despotic power when all of others
fail that the despot may be a good despot
& therefore may be safely trusted - & that the
trusting him is most convenient, expedi-
tious expeditious & consequently expedient - As to the
remedy which the author may have against
injustice - & the answer to the fear of insol
vency insolvency (page 36) that "Poverty & insolvency are evils
'Which it is not in the power of the law to cure"

This is not a fair answer in this particu
lar particular case because the rule in question exposes
the sufferer plaintiffto a chance of suffering by insol
vency without any imprudence of his own
- In other cases the creditor who has trusted an
insolvent has voluntarily run the risk - in
this case it is involuntary -

- The concluding argument page 40 concerning
The effect comparitive effects evil of permitting
the increased circulation of a few books of
mischievous tendency & the good of discou
raging discouraging
the a number of similar publications
appears to me also doubtful - But it would
lead beyond the compass of a letter & probably
beyond my reach to argue this question
fully - I may only observe however in ge-
neral general that all prohibatory laws against
smuggled books as against all other smug-
gled smuggled articles have tended rather to encrease
than diminish the trade & the demand -
In this case it is peculiarly the object of the
moral legislator to diminish the demand
to extinguish the wish to read imimmoral books

From All the experience of childhood,
youth and age I fear apprehend are against
the prohibitory system as to reading - In France
les livres defendus were disseminated &
fashionable formerly in proportion to the risk
& the price - Nothing is effectual but good
principles & good taste in extinguishing the
wish and demand for pernicious books
- with the demand the production ceases -
exactly upon your sons own argument
that the persons who produce such trash
are influenced in spite of shame & all other
motives prudential moral & religious by the hope of
gain - then to increase good taste & strengthen
principle must be the object & is not this
most likely to be effected by permitting that
freedom of the press which ensures free discus
sion discussion on literary taste & moral principle &
which diffuses with the blessings of education
the knowledge of truth & the power of discerning what
is
false - How much public taste for literature has been improved
within our own memory by the Edn & Quarterly Review
which act in the best way as Censors of the press
making it a censorship of opinion not of law
merely - Among the vast encreased number
of readers which these reviews have created
how small is the proportion of those who have
a taste for the pernicious books alluded to
The very fact of the extensive sale of the re-
views reviews shews the improved taste of the public
- However we may differ in opinion concern-
ing concerning the rival reviews & rival articles still we must
agree that this is wholesome respectable reading
compared with the immoral trash for which you
justly desire to diminish the taste & the demand

.- Your article on Mexico is extremely
interesting, and has all the charm of novelty
joined to accurate information - To your
sly inferences slid in in favor of the continu
ance continuance of negro slavery observe I do not accede
- But I dare not launch out on that boundless
sea of argument - If ever we meet you will
convince me in conversation - if you can -

I have no thoughts of being in England
this summer. The only or at least the chief
motive I had for thinking of leaving home was
to have taken my sister Fannythere and
this object is much better accomplished
by her going to pass some months with her
young married sister & kind brother in law
Mr. & Mrs. Fox who have invited her to do so - They are
at Cheltenham where she will join them in
the course of a fortnight & then go to some place on the sea coast I hope - and Under
their kind & quiet care, with a proper mix-
ture mixture of air excercise, rest & society she will
I trust recover strength & health - She is far
from well at present - yet nothing alarming

My aunt and uncle Buxton and all at Black
-Castle are much gratified by your kind remem
brance remembrance of them and of your visit here - My aunt
Buxton bids me tell you that in your travels in Spain she
found an account of a picture by Peatro di Campria in Seville
of the taking down from the cross - from which she has an
engraving in her dining room - She had long admired the
composition of the piece & rejoiced to find the name of the artist
and your account of the picture - whh. she has transcribed on the back of
the print - My friend Mrs. Marcet mentions a
sort of novel in French which she has been reading called Alonzo
- which though a bad imitation of Scott gives a curious
view of the manners of Spain during the revolution
- Do you know the book & what do you think of it -
Are you acquainted with Mrs. Marcet? or would you wish for an introduction - She is to
spend next winter in London - I am sure you would like her -
I have been much entertained with
Haggi Baba which I think beautifully written & in
which the Persian customs are so well introduced
- There is a vein of harmless wit & well bred saillery, - I can hardly
call it satire through the whole, which delights &
never goes against my conscience - I have never to
say to myself "I ought not to have smiled at that" -
Not so with Captn. Rock - There is a work of pro-
digious prodigious talent! - Yet I wish it had never been
published - I do not however wish that it had
been stopped, for a time by an injunction - for it would have
been doubly desired as a prohibited book- Now it
is open to fair criticism - & to the counteractive affects
of public opinion - Of the numbers who read it &
who admire the wit, learning, eloquence in which
it abounds almost nine in ten of, whom I have
heard speak of it agree in blaming the publication -

The length of the book will counteract the strength
Mr. Hume is very ill informed respecting plura
-lities pluralities in Ireland - He has made some gross & laughable
mistakes - But I suppose they are by this time detected
& exposed - if not I could tell you a few -

I recollect some excellent observations of yours
in one of your letters last year on the causes which
prevent the redundancy English capital from flowing over to Ireland -
- Insecure - chiefly - This we may hope is diminish
-ing diminishing - & in the best way, in consequence of the more ac
curate accurate knowledge & more just views England has
tained obtained of the state of this country & the consequent de-
sire desire of government to enforce impartial administra
tion administration of the laws and to discourage party oppression &
party vengeance on both sides - The examinations before
the Committees of the house of Commons have done much
good - The fact is made clear that wherever the people
in Ireland have obtained employment their disposition to
disturbance has diminished if not ceased altogether -
This single fact is of inestimable value - Then how to give
employment is the next pressing question - Nothing can come of
nothing - The Irish landlords cannot have not capital - English
Capitalists are afraid - But there is an old adage - Nothing
hazard nothing have - The hazard here is not equal to the
probability of gain (putting all benevolent motives out of view)
the fact above established proves this - viz - the disturbances
ceasing with the employment given - I am not sure that I have
made my meaning clear - but your clear head will make
it out -

There are a variety of mining companies & speculating
insurance companies opening in Dublin - I fear this
will not be ultimately beneficial - To give regular
habits of industry is what is wanted in this country &
this must follow from regular demand & supply
- not from the uncertain excitation of speculations
- gambling in short - The indolence & despair which
succeeds to disappointed exertion have been too often
seen in Ireland - The failure of Brooke of Prosperous
- the failure of Anderson of Fermoy - were much
greater misfortunes to Ireland than the failure of
two individuals could have been in England -
Because the impression left on the public mind was
"See how vain it is for public spirited people to lay
"out their money in manufactures or great establish
"ments in Ireland" -
If the Irish speculators could but be taught to look before they leap!
You English certainly do look well before they leap
- therefore they leap safely - The Scotch look too long
before they leap -
I am not sure whether I have written to you since
our excursion to Scotland - In one word I was delight
ed with it - and most of all with our 3 weeks visit
at Abbotsford - Scott is equal to his writings in conversation
As far as I can judge from the statements in the papers
Moore has behaved nobly about Lord Byron life - But from
what private letters from London hint I began to fear there
is something which I do not know & should be sorry to hear
- I am told Moore has not gained much in public opinion
by the transaction - how can that be when he has sacrificed Â£2000
to the wish not to give pain to Lord Byron's wife, sister & family and
to his desire not to publish what might be injurious -
Miss Buxton desires to be very kindly remembered
to you though your promised improvement
in Irish leather has never to her knowledge been
accomplished -
Remember me Dear Sir to all of your family
who care for me & continue your letters &
kindness to
div.closer:
your obliged Maria Edgeworth
W. Jacob Esqre
Receiver of Corn returns
Regents Street
London
